But besides this defect of accuracy in following out the plan he had laid down for himself (a defect which seriously diminishes the value of the information conveyed by his method) Gerbert’s way ⁴of regarding his materials had another unfortunate result. As he was inclined to minimise the differences of text between R. and S., he was also inclined to underrate‚ or to misunder- stand, the importance of the changes introduced into the latter manuscript by the hand of the corrector. These changes were, in many cases, much more than mere corrections of mistakes in grammar or variations in spelling. The effect, if not the purpose, of the corrector’s work has generally been the altera- tion of the original text into closer agreement with the text of the later Sacramentaries of the type known as ‘ Gregorian.’ Hence it comes to pass that the ‘ Gelasian ’ portions of the ⁸ triple text ' of Τ.
